No. Iron in the blood is'nt raw but combined with a red pigment called haem, and a larger protein molecule globulin (Haemoglobin). Unless you inject raw iron inside you and let it clump together (in which case you would die), it wont work.

Eyes are analog, so it's not really a matter of how many FPS the eye can actually see, because it is fluid.  Your eyes are not sending your brain a still image, and then subsequent 'recaptures'.  It is continuously 'seeing'.  The real question is how high of a rate of FPS can the human eye see before we do not notice increasing rates. In a magnet + superconductor system, magnetic levitation is allowed by the beautiful combination of two pretty antagonist effects : Meissner effect, intrinsic to superconductivity, which repels magnets, and vortices pinning, which tends to immobilize magnets. No wonder why superconductivity is so fascinating!!! :-)
Wow... The videos are getting a little over my level of understanding. But still love them though. :)

One can show that moving vortices results in creating a resistivity and increasing the energy of the material, which is not favored by Nature. However, the positions of vortices depend on the magnetic field which creates them. If the magnetic field were to change (which can be done by moving a magnet above a superconductor), the vortices would move : this is therefore not favored by Nature as it doesn't lower the free energy of the system. The magnet then stands still and levitates! :)

Within these vortices, there's no superconductivity. But these vortices are surrounded by the rest of the material which is still superconducting as long as the field is not higher than a critical field (often far greater than 1 tesla in YBaCuO). The superconducting part of the material repels the magnetic field but the vortices acts like little magnets in a strange way.

I didn't have enough letters in my first comment. ;-) A type I superconductor (like lead or mercury) will expel magnetic fields no matter what, except if the field is too strong (less than 1 tesla for these superconductors), superconductivity breaks beyond this field. A type II superconductor (like YBaCuO or some alloys for example) allows magnetic fields to enter it (if the field is sufficiently strong) through vortices, little regions where superconductivity breaks.

As a matter of fact, the repulsion of a magnetic field by a superconductor (or Meissner effect), is an intrinsic property of the superconducting state. When it was found in 1933, it was the proof that superconductivity was a new phase of matter since a completely new property emerged from it. It is a purely quantum effect. To understand magnetic levitation in the case of a magnet and a superconductor, you have to consider one important thing : the type of superconductor you're working with.

My rough understanding is that if you cool a material to below its superconducting critical temperature (Tc) while in (effectively) zero magnetic field, it'll lock in that lack of magnetic field, which is why it will expel external magnetic fields while it stays superconducting. If you cool it below Tc in a strong magnetic field, it'll lock in that strong field instead, and be a permanent magnet while it stays superconducting.
